ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I improved my writing skills and believe that I was able to learn how to write a college-level essay.

I got a better grasp on how to structure an essay in a way which makes the topic, problem, and claim clear and straightforward while still being engaging. I also learned how important it is to come to class prepared and having done and annotated the readings because days I did the readings were so much more enjoyable than days when I didn't do them or just skimmed them.
I learned how to read short articles and use insight from those articles in my writing. This class also improved my writing and confidence in writing.
I learned many new terms about modern and pre-modern literature and prose.
Writing skills. Reading skills. Culture knowledge.
I developed close reading skills as well as skills on how to write and organize a good paper.

Being more specific in my claim and purpose
Conversation about avante garde and kitsch and how it relates to guilty pleasure
I learned how to effectively build an argument in an essay using claims and evidence to analyze primary and secondary sources.
writing skils

To be perfectly honest, I don't think I got much out of this course. Part of it was the topic... I never felt that I fully understood what a "guilty pleasure" is, or perhaps, at least, I just don't have any.
In addition, and this is totally my fault, but I never had enough time to do the readings before class, so I was never prepared when class started. (Signing up for three separate classes that had weekly p-sets, plus a five-days-a-week language course, was not a good idea.)
I'm still not sure I actually know how to write an essay.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It felt like class sessions were too long at times, and we had a lot of awkward silences

A strength in my eyes was the subject matter, which makes sense because I picked the course out because it looked interesting so I am very glad I enjyed it. A lot of the readings were also super enlightening which was great. A weakness is that some of the readings were a little old-fashioned and dense so it was hard to really understand them outside of class and come to class prepared. There was also little incentive to really engage with the readings outside of class because there were no reading responses or reading checks.

My favorite classes were the ones where we presented to the class and the students led the conversations. I think if we were forced/assigned to do that more, students would come more prepared to class.
I liked the material. I didn't like how all the essay prompts were similar.
Good course.
Honestly this was a great class all around. I think it could be improved by diving deeper into the idea of a guilty pleasure and doing more creative projects / papers on this subject.

Strengths: 
very engaging papers, great feedback, good structure and deadlines, great professor
Weakness:
not much writing guidance in the class, mostly essay analysis conversation which was still great but

The materials that we read in and out of class were very strongly related to the theme of the course and helped build an understanding of guilty pleasures as a whole. Some of the materials were difficult to follow and it could be helpful to analyze more.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I think it is a good course for freshman looking to improve their writing and bring it to the university level.

I would. The teaching fellow, Gabrielle Reid, was very capable and although the discussion in class was sometimes a little slow, when everyone came prepared and engaged we got into some super interesting topics. I also really enjoyed all the papers. The prompts were just broad enough so that I could put my own spin on it, but they were structured in a way that kept me on track and focused. The workload was very reasonable and mostly enjoyable.
Yes
Yes, it a great class to take as a first year and improve your writing.
Yes, it was entertaining and I enjoyed the teacher's thoughts.
Yes. Fun.
I would definitely recommend this course it was such an interesting class.
Yes, I am more confident in my college writing now than I was before taking the course

I thought the topic of this seminar was very interesting and I would recommend this course to a student with similar interests. The reading materials helped facilitate positive learning and discussion.
yes

I am very STEM-oriented. Especially given my experience this semester and last semester, I know that I have a much harder time in a writing class than in a math or science class. In addition, I don't follow sports, celebrities, pop music, or many of the TV shows discussed in class, so I felt very disconnected from the subject matter. Depending on who this other student is, I may or may not recommend this course.
